questions.text: A patient presented with a fall on an outstretched hand. On X-ray, a fracture of the base of the 1st metacarpal bone was seen. This type of fracture is also known as: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Bennett’s fracture

 

The fracture described in the question is a fracture of the base of the first metacarpal bone, which is characteristic of a Bennett's fracture. Bennett's fracture is an intra-articular fracture of the base of the first metacarpal, which extends into the carpometacarpal (CMC) joint. This type of fracture usually results from a force applied to the thumb during a fall on an outstretched hand.

 

The fracture typically results in a dislocation of the metacarpal from the trapezium due to the pull of the abductor pollicis longus muscle. On an X-ray, this fracture often appears as an oblique break at the base of the metacarpal, with a small fragment remaining attached to the trapezium.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Monteggia fracture: This involves a fracture of the proximal third of the ulna with dislocation of the head of the radius. It does not involve the first metacarpal and thus is not the correct answer.

 

Option C. Colle’s fracture: This is a distal radius fracture with dorsal angulation, typically resulting from a fall on an outstretched hand. It does not involve the first metacarpal, so this option is incorrect.

 

Option D. Smith’s fracture: This is also a distal radius fracture but with volar angulation. Similar to Colle’s fracture, it does not involve the first metacarpal, making it incorrect for this scenario.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Bennett's fracture is an intra-articular fracture at the base of the first metacarpal bone, commonly caused by a fall on an outstretched hand. It is important to recognize this fracture due to its involvement with the CMC joint and potential for dislocation.

questions.text: A lesion of the structure marked in the image below cause?(AIIMS May 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Contralateral hemiplegia

 

Explanation:

 

The structure marked in the image is the pyramid containing the pyramidal tracts. A lesion here leads to contralateral hemiplegia.

 

This is because the fibers of these tracts decussate (cross over) in the medulla oblongata. Thus, an injury to the pyramidal tract on one side of the brain or upper spinal cord will affect motor function on the opposite side of the body.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Ataxia: Ataxia refers to uncoordinated movement and is typically related to damage to the cerebellum or sensory pathways, not the pyramidal tracts. The cerebellum plays a crucial role in fine-tuning motor movements and ensuring coordination. So, an injury to the pyramidal tracts does not typically result in ataxia.

 

Option C. Tinnitus: Tinnitus is the perception of noise or ringing in the ears. It's a symptom of an underlying condition, such as age-related hearing loss, ear injury, or a circulatory system disorder. Injury to the pyramidal tracts would not lead to tinnitus, as they are primarily motor tracts and not involved in auditory processing or function.

 

Option D. Ipsilateral facial palsy: Facial palsy refers to weakness or paralysis of the muscles on one side of the face. It is most commonly associated with damage to the facial nerve (cranial nerve VII). While the pyramidal tracts do play a role in voluntary facial movements, a direct injury to these tracts would not typically lead to ipsilateral facial palsy. Furthermore, facial movements are controlled by both sides of the brain, so an isolated pyramidal tract lesion might not manifest as overt facial weakness.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The pyramids in the medulla oblongata, containing the pyramidal tracts, are crucial for voluntary motor control. A lesion here can lead to contralateral hemiplegia due to the crossing over of these tracts within the medulla. This understanding is essential for diagnosing and understanding the implications of brainstem injuries, especially in the context of stroke or other neurological disorders.

questions.text: Name the joint formed between the epiphysis and diaphysis of a long bone: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Synchondrosis

 

The joint formed between the epiphysis and diaphysis of a long bone is known as a synchondrosis. Synchondrosis is a type of primary cartilaginous joint where bones are joined by hyaline cartilage. In the context of long bones, this joint occurs between the epiphyseal plate (growth plate) and the diaphysis during the development of the bone.

 

The epiphyseal plate is a layer of hyaline cartilage that allows the bone to grow in length. As growth continues, this cartilage eventually undergoes ossification, transforming into bone and thereby eliminating the synchondrosis joint, marking the end of growth in length.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Syndesmosis: This is a fibrous joint where bones are connected by a ligament or a sheet of fibrous tissue. It does not involve cartilage and is therefore not applicable to the junction between the epiphysis and diaphysis.

 

Option C. Synarthrosis: Synarthrosis refers to an immovable joint. While synchondrosis could be considered a type of synarthrosis when ossified, it specifically refers to the cartilaginous joint prior to ossification. Thus, this option is less specific and not the correct answer in this context.

 

Option D. Symphysis: Symphysis is a secondary cartilaginous joint where bones are joined by fibrocartilage. It is typically found in the midline of the body, such as the pubic symphysis or the intervertebral discs. This type of joint does not describe the connection between the epiphysis and diaphysis of a long bone.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The joint formed between the epiphysis and diaphysis of a long bone during development is a synchondrosis, which is a primary cartilaginous joint composed of hyaline cartilage that eventually ossifies as growth completes.

questions.text:
Identify the incorrectly matched pair(s) of pharyngeal arch and its artery? (Twisted PYQ)

  1. 1st arch - Maxillary artery
  2. 2nd arch - Hyoid and stapedial artery
  3. 3rd arch - Internal carotid artery
  4. 4th arch - Aortic arch on the right side
  5. 6th arch - Pulmonary artery on both sides
questions.solution:
Ans. C) iv

 

Explanation:

 

The 4th pharyngeal arch artery has asymmetrical development:

  • Left side: Forms part of the aortic arch
  • Right side: Forms proximal part of right subclavian artery

 

Statement 4 is incorrect because it states the 4th arch forms aortic arch on right side, which is anatomically impossible.

 

Other statements:

 

  1. Correct. 1st arch forms maxillary artery
  2. Correct. 2nd arch develops into hyoid and stapedial arteries
  3. Correct. 3rd arch forms internal carotid arteries
  4. Correct. 6th arch forms: 
    • Left side: Ductus arteriosus and left pulmonary artery
    • Right side: Right pulmonary artery

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Asymmetrical development of 4th pharyngeal arch arteries is crucial - left forms part of definitive aortic arch while right contributes to right subclavian artery. This asymmetry is fundamental to normal cardiovascular development.

questions.text: The middle radioulnar joint is an example of a: (INICET Nov 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Fibrous joint

 

Explanation:

 

The middle radioulnar joint is an example of a fibrous joint (syndesmosis).

 

Fibrous joints are joints where bones are connected by fibrous tissue, such as ligaments or sutures.

 

Examples of fibrous joints include the sutures of the skull and the syndesmosis between the radius and ulna at the distal radioulnar joint.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Plane synovial: Plane synovial joints are also known as gliding joints. They allow for limited gliding or sliding movements between flat articular surfaces. Examples of plane synovial joints include the intercarpal joints of the wrist.

 

Option B. Primary cartilaginous: Primary cartilaginous joints, also called synchondroses, are joints where bones are connected by hyaline cartilage. An example of a primary cartilaginous joint is the epiphyseal plate in growing long bones.

 

Option C. Secondary cartilaginous: Secondary cartilaginous joints, or symphyses, are joints where bones are connected by fibrocartilage. Examples include the intervertebral discs and the pubic symphysis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Three joints connect the radius and ulna to one another:

 

  • Proximal (superior) radioulnar joint
  • Middle radioulnar joint
  • Distal (inferior) radioulnar joint

 

Proximal and distal radioulnar joints are uniaxial pivot joints (synovial) and are involved in pronation and supination movements of the forearm.

 

The middle radioulnar joint is a fibrous joint (syndesmosis). The radius and ulna, in the middle, are connected by two syndesmoses namely:

 

  1. The oblique cord - extends distally from the radial tuberosity to the radius from the lateral side of the ulnar tuberosity.
  2. Interosseous membrane - a broad, thin collagenous structure, which runs perpendicular to the oblique cord. It extends distomedially between the interosseous borders of the radius and ulna.

questions.text: In which of the following locations does meiosis normally occur in the human body? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Adult ovary

 

Meiosis occurs in the adult ovary.

 

  • Meiosis is the process by which gametes (sperm and eggs) are produced in sexually reproducing organisms.
  • It occurs only in germ cells and leads to the formation of haploid gametes.
  • To reduce the number of chromosomes to the haploid number of 23, meiosis requires two cell divisions, meiosis I and meiosis II.
  • In females, meiosis occurs in the ovaries during fetal development, but is arrested in prophase I until puberty.
  • After puberty, meiosis resumes and one ovum is produced each month.
  • In males, meiosis occurs in the testes and produces sperm.
  • Meiosis in the testes begins during puberty and continues throughout adulthood.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Adrenal: The adrenal glands are located atop each kidney and are involved in the production of various hormones, such as cortisol, aldosterone, and sex steroids. Meiosis, the process by which germ cells divide to produce gametes with half the number of chromosomes, does not occur in the adrenal glands. Instead, the adrenal glands are involved in steroidogenesis or the production of steroid hormones.

 

Option C. Prepubertal testis: The testes are the male reproductive organs that produce spermatozoa (sperm cells) and testosterone. In males, meiosis begins during puberty. In the prepubertal testis, the germ cells are not yet undergoing meiosis to form mature sperm cells. These germ cells (spermatogonia) proliferate by mitosis during childhood but only enter meiosis to become spermatocytes and eventually mature spermatozoa after the onset of puberty.

 

Option D. Hypothalamus: It is a region of the brain responsible for various vital functions, including the release of hormones that regulate the pituitary gland. It is not involved in meiosis. Instead, it plays an essential role in regulating various physiological processes, such as body temperature, thirst, hunger, and circadian rhythms. It also plays a significant role in controlling the release of hormones from the anterior pituitary by producing releasing or inhibiting hormones.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Adult ovaries are responsible for producing ova (egg cells) and hormones such as estrogen and progesterone. Meiosis begins in the fetal ovaries but is arrested in prophase I until puberty.

 

After puberty, with each menstrual cycle, some oocytes resume meiosis, completing meiosis I and arresting in meiosis II. It's only after fertilization that meiosis II completes. Therefore, meiosis occurs in the adult ovary as it is essential for the formation of mature ova or egg cells.

questions.text: A patient came with complaints of inability to move his 4th and 5th digit, cannot hold a pen and he was not able to hold a paper between fingers. Which of the following sites given below is the probable cause of injury to the nerve in question? (AIIMS Nov 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. 7

 

The given clinical scenario of a patient complaining of inability to move his 4th and 5th digit, not able to hold a pen and also not able to hold paper between fingers, all together suggests towards an ulnar nerve injury. The most likely site of injury would thus be medial epicondyle – structure marked as 7.

 

Given below is the labelling of the structures marked in the figure -

 

  1. Head
  2. Greater Tubercle
  3. Intertubercular Groove
  4. Deltoid Tuberosity
  5. Capitulum
  6. Trochlea
  7. Medial Epicondyle
  8. Olecranon Fossa
  9. Lateral Epicondyle
  10. Lesser Tubercle

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 1: Head of Humerus: This area is not typically associated with isolated ulnar nerve injuries. Injuries here affect the axillary nerve.

 

Option C. 9: Lateral Epicondyle: The lateral epicondyle is more commonly associated with injuries affecting the radial nerve or conditions like lateral epicondylitis (tennis elbow).

 

Option D. 4: Deltoid Tuberosity: This site on the humerus is typically associated with the attachment of the deltoid muscle. Injuries or issues here would more likely affect the deltoid muscle or the radial nerve dysfunction.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tests for ulnar nerve lesions are as follows:

 

1. Card Test: This isn't a widely recognized test in the context of ulnar nerve pathology. However, in some practices, the card test might refer to asking the patient to hold a card (like a credit card) between their thumb and the side of their index finger. Difficulty or inability to do this due to a weak adductor pollicis muscle (innervated by the ulnar nerve) may suggest ulnar nerve dysfunction.

 

2. Claw Hand Deformity: This is seen in ulnar nerve injuries. In a typical ulnar claw hand, the 4th and 5th digits (ring and little fingers) are hyperextended at the metacarpophalangeal (MCP) joints and flexed at the interphalangeal (IP) joints. This occurs due to the loss of function of the lumbricals and interossei of the hand, which are innervated by the ulnar nerve.

 

3. Froment's Sign: This is a classic sign of ulnar nerve palsy. The patient is asked to hold a piece of paper between their thumb and the side of their index finger (pinch grip). If the ulnar nerve is compromised, the patient will compensate by flexing the thumb's IP joint to maintain grip strength, which is a positive Froment's sign. This indicates weakness or paralysis of the adductor pollicis muscle.

 

4. Wartenberg Sign: In ulnar nerve injury, there's unopposed action of the extensor digiti minimi, which leads to abduction of the little finger. The patient will be unable to bring their little finger back to the side of the hand, leading to the "Wartenberg sign."

 

5. Palmaris Brevis Sign: This is a sign of ulnar nerve functionality. The palmaris brevis muscle is innervated by the ulnar nerve. Upon tapping or massaging the hypothenar eminence (palm side of the hand, base of the little finger), contraction of the palmaris brevis muscle can be observed as a twitching or dimpling. If present, it indicates that at least part of the ulnar nerve's function remains intact.

questions.text:
Which muscles receive innervation from the Superior Gluteal Nerve? (INICET MAY 2023)

 

1. Gluteus Medius

2. Gluteus Minimus

3. Tensor fascia lata

4. Piriformis
questions.solution:
Ans. C. 1, 2, 3

 

Superior Gluteal Nerve (L4, L5, S1) supplies to Gluteus Medius, Minimus and Tensor Fascia Lata (damage leads to positive Trendelenburg sign). Accompanied by the superior gluteal vessels, the nerve leaves the pelvis via the greater sciatic foramen above piriformis, and divides into superior and inferior branches. The superior branch accompanies the upper branch of the deep division of the superior gluteal artery to supply gluteus medius and occasionally gluteus minimus. The inferior branch runs with the lower ramus of the deep division of the superior gluteal artery across gluteus minimus, supplies the glutei medius and minimus and ends in tensor fasciae latae.

 

Piriformis is supplied by the nerve to the piriformis (S1, S2).

 

 

1. Gluteus Medius: True. The gluteus medius muscle receives innervation from the superior gluteal nerve. This nerve supplies motor neurons to the gluteus medius and plays a crucial role in the abduction and stabilization of the hip joint.
 

2. Gluteus Minimus: True. Similar to the gluteus medius, the gluteus minimus muscle is also innervated by the superior gluteal nerve. It functions in hip abduction and stabilization.
 

3. Tensor Fascia Lata (TFL): True. The tensor fascia lata muscle, often referred to as the TFL, receives innervation from the superior gluteal nerve. This muscle assists in various movements, including flexion, abduction, and medial rotation of the hip.

 

Other Option

 

4. Piriformis: False. The piriformis muscle is not innervated by the superior gluteal nerve. Instead, it is primarily innervated by the nerve to the piriformis, which arises from the sacral plexus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Gluteus Medius, Gluteus Minimus, and Tensor Fascia Lata receive innervation from the Superior Gluteal Nerve (L4, L5, and S1 nerve roots). Piriformis, on the other hand, is innervated by one of the branch of sacral plexus.

questions.text: All of the following supply the structure marked ‘E’ except? (AIIMS Nov 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Diagonal artery

 

The right ventricle is the marked object. The diagonal arterial supply does not reach it.

 

The anterior interventricular artery, which supplies the left ventricle, has a branch called the diagonal artery. Between 30 to 50 percent of the population has this.

 

The right coronary artery and its branches, including the marginal artery, provide the right ventricle with the majority of its blood.

 

One or two anterior right ventricular branches emerge from the anterior interventricular artery.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Right coronary artery: This is correct in terms of not being an exception. The right coronary artery primarily supplies the right atrium and the right ventricle, including the structure marked as 'E', which is the right ventricle.

 

Option B. Anterior interventricular artery: This artery primarily supplies the interventricular septum and the anterior walls of both ventricles. Although it predominantly serves the left ventricle, it also sends branches such as the anterior right ventricular branches that can reach the right ventricle.

 

Option C. Marginal artery: This artery, a branch of the right coronary artery, specifically supplies the right ventricle, which is the structure marked as 'E'.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Understanding the vascular supply of the heart is crucial, especially in clinical settings dealing with coronary artery disease. The right ventricle is primarily supplied by the right coronary artery and its branches, including the marginal artery. The diagonal artery, a branch of the left coronary system (specifically the anterior interventricular artery), mainly supplies the left ventricle and does not contribute significantly to the blood supply of the right ventricle.

questions.text:
What are the derivatives of the marked cells? (INICET MAY 2022)

 

1. Odontoblasts

2. Sympathetic chain

3. Melanocytes

4. Nephrogenic cord

5. Bulbus cordis

6. Conotruncal septum
questions.solution:
Ans. C. 1, 2, 3, 6

 

Explanation

 

The cells referred to in the question are neural crest cells (NCC), identified adjacent to the neural tube (NT). These cells are significant in developmental biology and are often considered a fourth germ layer due to their extensive differentiation potential across various organs and tissues, exclusive to vertebrates. NCCs transform into various cell types based on their migration path:

 

Dorsal region migration leads to the formation of sensory neurons.

 

Ventral region migration results in the differentiation into sympathetic neurons.

 

These cells are pivotal in developing peripheral nervous system components, craniofacial structures (including bones, cartilage, teeth, and facial muscles), and cardiovascular system components such as the heart.

 

1. Odontoblasts : Correct, as these are the cells responsible for dentin formation in teeth, derived from neural crest cells.

 

2. Sympathetic chain : Correct, neural crest cells form the sympathetic ganglia, part of the autonomic nervous system.

 

3. Melanocytes : Correct, these pigment-producing cells in the skin and hair are derived from neural crest cells.

 

6. Conotruncal septum : Correct, this component of the heart, crucial for the division of the pulmonary artery and aorta, is derived from neural crest cells.

 

In trunk region, NCC form:

 

  • Melanocytes
  • Sensory ganglia
  • Sympathetic and enteric neurons
  • Schwann cells
  • Adrenal medulla cells
  • In the cranial region, they contribute to the:
  • Craniofacial skeleton
  • Neurons for cranial ganglia
  • Satellite glial cells
  • Melanocytes
  • Some of the other neural crest derivatives are
  • C cells of the thyroid gland
  • Conotruncal septum in the heart
  • Odontoblasts
  • Smooth muscle cells to blood vessels to the face and forebrain.

 

Other Options:

 

4. Nephrogenic cord : Incorrect, as it is involved in the development of the kidneys and does not derive from neural crest cells.

 

5. Bulbus cordis : Incorrect, this embryonic heart structure does not originate from neural crest cells.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Neural crest cells (NCCs), stemming from the embryonic ectoderm and unique to vertebrates, play an essential role in forming various tissues and organs like the peripheral nervous system and craniofacial structures during development. These cells migrate and differentiate into diverse cell types based on their location in the body, contributing significantly to the development of sensory and sympathetic neurons, craniofacial elements, and cardiovascular structures.

questions.text: What is the nerve supply of the structure marked by red arrow in the image below? (AIIMS Nov 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Trochlear nerve

 

Explanation:

 

The structure marked in the image is the superior oblique muscle. It is innervated by the trochlear nerve.

 

 

There are seven extraocular muscles present in the eye. They are:

 

  • Levator palpebrae superioris - Which elevates the upper eyelids
  • Four recti muscles - Superior, inferior, medial, and lateral recti
  • Two obliques - Superior and inferior oblique

 

The muscles originate from the back of the orbit in a common tendinous ring called the annulus of Zinn and are inserted into the sclera.

 

All the extraocular muscles are innervated by the oculomotor (III) except Superior Oblique (Trochlear nerve, IV) and Lateral rectus (Abducens, VI)

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Oculomotor nerve: This nerve innervates most of the extraocular muscles except for the superior oblique and the lateral rectus. It does not innervate the structure marked in the image, which is the superior oblique muscle.

 

Option C. Trigeminal nerve: This nerve primarily provides sensory innervation to the face and does not innervate any of the extraocular muscles, including the superior oblique.

 

Option D. Abducens nerve: This nerve innervates the lateral rectus muscle only, which abducts the eye. It does not innervate the superior oblique muscle.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The superior oblique muscle, is uniquely innervated by the trochlear nerve (cranial nerve IV), which is the only cranial nerve that exits the brainstem dorsally. This muscle functions to depress, abduct, and internally rotate the eyeball, and it is the only extraocular muscle innervated by the trochlear nerve. Remembering this specific innervation is crucial for diagnosing and managing ocular motility disorders.

questions.text: Which of the following layers is absent in the esophagus?(FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Serosa

 

Explanation:

 

The esophagus is a tubular structure located in the thoracic cavity, connecting the pharynx to the stomach. Unlike most of the gastrointestinal tract, the esophagus lacks a serosa layer. The serosa is a thin membrane derived from the peritoneum, which is a structure found in the abdominal cavity. Since the esophagus is primarily located in the thoracic cavity, it does not have a serosa layer covering its external surface.

 

However, it is important to note that the short, intra-abdominal portion of the esophagus (just before it connects to the stomach) is covered by a serosa layer derived from the peritoneum. This portion is an exception to the general rule that the esophagus lacks a serosa.

 

The esophageal wall is composed of the following layers from the lumen outwards:

 

  1. Mucosa: The innermost layer, consisting of epithelium, lamina propria, and muscularis mucosae.
  2. Submucosa: A layer of connective tissue containing blood vessels, lymphatics, and esophageal glands.
  3. Muscularis externa (or muscularis propria): Consists of an inner circular layer and an outer longitudinal layer of smooth muscle.
  4. Adventitia: The outermost layer of the esophagus, composed of loose connective tissue. This layer is not called serosa because it is not derived from the peritoneum.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Mucosa: Incorrect. The mucosa is present in the esophagus and forms the innermost layer.

 

Option B. Submucosa: Incorrect. The submucosa is present in the esophagus and lies between the mucosa and muscularis externa.

 

Option C. Muscularis externa: Incorrect. The muscularis externa is present in the esophagus and consists of two layers of smooth muscle.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The esophagus lacks a serosa layer because it is primarily located in the thoracic cavity, except for the short intra-abdominal portion just before it connects to the stomach.

questions.text: A young patient presented with hypoparathyroidism, absent thymus and tetany. Which of the following marked areas in the picture is defective in this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. 12

 

Explanation:

 

The given clinical scenario of hypoparathyroidism, absent thymus, and tetany is suggestive of DiGeorge syndrome. It is caused by defective development of the third and fourth pharyngeal pouch.

 

In the image of pharyngeal pouches, "12" points to the thymus (derivative of 3rd pharyngeal pouch). Since in the above question, the thymus is absent, option 3 will be the most appropriate answer.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. (1): 1st Pharyngeal pouches, which is unrelated to the thymus or parathyroid glands directly involved in this case.

 

Option B. (10): External auditory meatus, which is not implicated in DiGeorge syndrome.

 

Option D. (13): Superior parathyroid gland, derived from the fourth pharyngeal pouch. Although it's closely related to the condition described, the primary indicator in this scenario, given the patient's symptoms, is the thymus rather than the parathyroid glands.

 

Educational Objective:

 

DiGeorge syndrome, also known as 22q11.2 deletion syndrome, is a genetic disorder caused by a missing piece of chromosome 22. It is characterized by a wide range of symptoms that can vary in severity, but are typically grouped together as mnemonic CATCH -22

 

Mnemonic "CATCH-22":

 

C - Cardiac abnormalities, such as ventricular septal defects (VSD) and tetralogy of Fallot.

 

A - Abnormal facies, including a small chin, low-set ears, and wide-set eyes.

 

T - Thymic aplasia or hypoplasia, leading to a weakened immune system.

 

C - Cleft palate or other palate abnormalities.

 

H - Hypocalcemia or low levels of calcium due to underdeveloped or missing parathyroid glands.

 

22 - Refers to the chromosome 22q11.2 deletion, which causes the syndrome.

choices.text: Keratinized epithelium, submucosa, minor salivary glands
Keratinized epithelium, absent submucosa, no salivary glands
Non-keratinized epithelium, submucosa, minor salivary glands
Non-keratinized epithelium, absent submucosa, minor salivary glands

questions.text: During a histological examination of the oral cavity, which combination of features is typically seen in the hard palate mucosa? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Keratinized epithelium, submucosa, minor salivary glands

 

Hard palate is composed of a dense layer of connective tissue covered by a specialized oral mucosa. It is composed of keratinized epithelium, a submucosal layer for support, and contains minor salivary glands. These structures contribute to the function of the hard palate in speech, mastication (chewing), and the initial digestion of food in the oral cavity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The hard palate is composed of keratinized epithelium to withstand mechanical stress, a submucosa that provides structural support, and contains minor salivary glands, which are essential for the lubrication and initial digestion of food. This structural composition is crucial for its function in the oral cavity.

questions.text: Identify the ocular component that originates from neural crest cells. (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Choroid

 

Explanation:

 

The choroid is derived from neural crest cells during embryonic development. Neural crest cells are a special population of cells that originate from the neural tube's edges. During eye development, these cells migrate to form various ocular structures including the choroid, which is the vascular layer between the retina and sclera. The choroid is part of the uveal tract and provides nutrients to the outer retinal layers through its rich vascular network.

 

Note - There is a controversy regarding the correct answer of this question. Our answer is based on Gray's Anatomy, 42nd edition which says "The choroid and sclera differentiate as inner vascular and outer fibrous layers, respectively, from the neural crest mesenchyme that surrounds the optic cup"

 

Other Options:

  • Option A. Descemet's membrane: This is not derived from neural crest cells but from neural ectoderm. It's the basement membrane of the corneal endothelium and is secreted by the endothelial cells.
  • Option B. Extraocular muscles: These develop from the mesoderm (specifically from prechordal mesoderm and somitomeres), not from neural crest cells. They include the six muscles that control eye movement.
  • Option C. Vitreous body: This clear gel filling the posterior segment of the eye develops primarily from mesenchymal cells of mesodermal origin, not neural crest cells.

 

Education Objective: 

 

Neural crest cells contribute significantly to ocular development, giving rise to the choroid, corneal endothelium, stroma, melanocytes, ciliary body, and iris stroma, but not to structures like Descemet's membrane, extraocular muscles, or the vitreous body.

questions.text: What is the function of the muscle marked in the image below, at the metacarpophalangeal joint?(NEET PG  2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Flexion

 

  • The primary function of the muscle marked is to facilitate flexion of the finger at the metacarpophalangeal joint. Flexion involves bending the finger, reducing the angle between the metacarpal bone (in the palm) and the proximal phalanx (the first bone of the finger). This muscle contributes to the closing of the fingers into a grip.
  • Muscles Involved are Flexor Digitorum Profundus,  Flexor Digitorum Superficialis, Flexor Pollicis Longus , Flexor Carpi Ulnaris and Flexor Carpi Radialis: These muscles flex the wrist.

 

 

 

  • Lumbricals are the muscles that cause flexion at the metacarpophalangeal joints.
  • The tendons of the flexor digitorum profundus in the palm give rise to the 4 lumbrical (worm-like) muscles.
  • Medial two lumbricals are bipennate and originate from the flexor digitorum profundus tendons associated with the middle and ring fingers and the ring and little fingers, respectively;Supplied by the deep branch of the ulnar nerve
  • Lateral two lumbricals are unipennate muscles, originating from the flexor digitorum profundus tendons associated with index and middle fingers, respectively; Supplied by digital branches of the median nerve
  • The lumbrical muscles have tendons that pass over the outer side of each finger and attach to the extensor hood. They are located in front of the deep transverse metacarpal ligaments.

 

The muscle marked in the image, at the metacarpophalangeal joint, is likely involved in finger movement.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Extension (Incorrect): Extension of the finger is the opposite movement of flexion. It involves straightening the finger, increasing the angle between the metacarpal bone and the proximal phalanx. The muscle in question is not primarily responsible for extension. Muscles Involved are Extensor Digitorum, Extensor Pollicis Longus , Extensor Carpi Ulnaris and Extensor Carpi Radialis.

 

Option C. Adduction (Incorrect): Adduction of the finger would involve moving the finger toward the midline or toward adjacent fingers. The muscle in the image is not oriented to perform adduction. Adduction of the fingers typically involves the intrinsic muscles of the hand, which are located within the hand itself

 

Option D. Abduction (Incorrect): Abduction of the finger would involve moving the finger away from the midline or away from adjacent fingers. The muscle in the image is not positioned to perform abduction. The specific muscles responsible for abduction are part of the dorsal interossei and palmar interossei muscle group

 

Educational Objective:

 

The lumbricals are essential for the flexion of the fingers at the metacarpophalangeal joints, contributing significantly to the dexterity and functional complexity of the hand, particularly in actions that require a combination of flexing and extending different joints of the fingers, such as typing or playing certain musical instruments.

questions.text: The talocalcaneonavicular joint is a?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Ball and socket joint

 

Explanation:

 

The talocalcaneonavicular joint is a ball and socket joint.

 

  • The ball part is formed by the rounded head of the talus.
  • The socket is formed by 3 structures:
    • Posterior surface of the navicular
    • Anterior articular surface of the calcaneus
    • Upper surface of the plantar calcaneo-navicular ligament (spring ligament).

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Saddle Type: A saddle joint, also known as a sellar joint, is a type of synovial joint found in the thumb (between the trapezium bone and the first metacarpal bone). It allows movement in two planes, such as flexion-extension and abduction-adduction. The talocalcaneonavicular joint does not fit this description.

 

Option B. Plane: A plane joint, also called a gliding joint, allows for limited sliding or gliding movements between flat articular surfaces. While there are gliding joints in the foot, the talocalcaneonavicular joint is not primarily classified as a plane joint.

 

Option C. Ellipsoid (Condyloid): An ellipsoid joint, also known as a condyloid joint, is a synovial joint that allows movement in two planes: flexion-extension and abduction-adduction. This type of joint has an oval-shaped convex surface fitting into an elliptical concave surface.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A ball and socket joint is characterized by a spherical head fitting into a cup-like socket. This type of joint allows for a wide range of motion in multiple planes. The talocalcaneonavicular joint is  a ball and socket joint.

questions.text: What is the nerve supply of the structure marked in the image?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Median nerve

 

Explanation:

 

The median nerve supplies the 1st lumbrical which is marked.

 

The 1st lumbrical muscle is innervated by the median nerve. It is a small, quadrilateral muscle located in the hand that arises from the tendon of the flexor digitorum profundus muscle of the index finger and inserts into the extensor expansion of the index finger. Its main function is to flex the metacarpophalangeal joint of the index finger and extend the interphalangeal joints of the index finger. The 1st lumbrical muscle is named because it is associated with the first (index) finger, and there are a total of four lumbrical muscles in the hand - one for each of the four fingers (excluding the thumb).

 

The first and second lumbrical nerves are innervated by the median nerve. The third and fourth lumbricals are innervated by the deep terminal branch of the ulnar nerve.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Radial Nerve: The radial nerve primarily innervates the extensor muscles of the forearm and hand, including the wrist and finger extensors. It does not supply the lumbrical muscles.

 

Option C. Ulnar Nerve: The ulnar nerve supplies several intrinsic hand muscles, including the lumbrical muscles. However, the first lumbrical is typically innervated by the median nerve, as mentioned earlier.

 

Option D. Musculocutaneous Nerve: The musculocutaneous nerve primarily innervates the muscles in the anterior compartment of the arm. It does not supply the lumbrical muscles.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The 1st lumbrical muscle of the hand is innervated by the median nerve is crucial for clinical assessments of hand function, especially in cases of nerve injury or compression syndromes like carpal tunnel syndrome, where the median nerve's functionality can be compromised.

questions.text: Which of the following sensations is not perceived by the spinal nucleus of the trigeminal nerve?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Proprioception

 

Explanation:

 

Proprioception refers to the sense of the relative position of body parts and the strength of effort being employed in movement. It provides the brain with information about limb position, movement, and force. It is perceived by the mesencephalic nucleus of the trigeminal nerve, not the spinal nucleus.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Temperature: Temperature sensation refers to the ability of the body to perceive differences in external and internal temperatures.

 

  • Relation to Spinal Nucleus of Trigeminal Nerve: The spinal nucleus of the trigeminal nerve plays a key role in mediating temperature sensations from the face. It receives input from the descending or spinal tract of the trigeminal nerve for temperature sensation from the face.

 

Option B. Pain: Pain is an unpleasant sensory and emotional experience associated with actual or potential tissue damage.

 

  • Relation to Spinal Nucleus of Trigeminal Nerve: The spinal nucleus is responsible for pain sensation from the face. Pain fibers from the face descend along the spinal tract of the trigeminal nerve and synapse in the spinal nucleus of the trigeminal nerve.

 

Option C. Touch: Touch or tactile sensation refers to the ability of the body to perceive pressure or contact with the skin.

 

  • Relation to Spinal Nucleus of Trigeminal Nerve: Light touch from the face is also processed by the spinal nucleus, but it's worth noting that discriminative touch (ability to recognize specific shapes and textures) from the face is primarily processed by the main or chief sensory nucleus of the trigeminal nerve, not the spinal nucleus.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

The trigeminal nerve consists of 4 nuclei:

questions.text: Which structure passes through the marked opening?(FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Thoracic duct

 

Explanation:

 

The arrow points to the diaphragm's aortic hiatus. It is crossed by the thoracic duct.

 

Structures passing through the aortic opening are:

 

  • Aorta
  • Thoracic duct
  • Azygous vein
  • Hemiazygous vein

 

 

The diaphragm is a thin, dome-shaped muscle that separates the thoracic cavity (containing the heart and lungs) from the abdominal cavity (containing the digestive organs). It has several structures passing through it, each serving important functions. Let's discuss the structures passing through the diaphragm in detail:

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Vena Cava (Inferior and Superior):

 

  • The Inferior Vena Cava (IVC) is a large vein that carries deoxygenated blood from the lower half of the body to the right atrium of the heart. It passes through the central tendon of the diaphragm, entering the right atrium just above the diaphragm.
  • The Superior Vena Cava (SVC) is another large vein that carries deoxygenated blood from the upper half of the body to the right atrium. It pierces the diaphragm at the level of the 3rd thoracic vertebra.

 

Option C. Esophagus: The Esophagus is a muscular tube that carries food and liquids from the mouth to the stomach for digestion. It passes through an opening in the diaphragm called the "esophageal hiatus." The diaphragm helps prevent stomach acid from flowing back into the esophagus, contributing to the prevention of acid reflux.

 

Option D. Phrenic Nerve: The Phrenic Nerve is a paired nerve (right and left) that originates from the cervical spinal nerves (C3, C4, and C5) and descends through the neck and thorax. It supplies motor and sensory innervation to the diaphragm, enabling it to contract and control breathing. The phrenic nerves pass through the diaphragm on both sides, allowing for coordinated breathing movements.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Thoracic Duct is the largest lymphatic vessel in the body. It collects lymph from the lower limbs, pelvis, abdomen, left thorax, left upper limb, and left side of the head and neck. The thoracic duct passes through the diaphragm to drain lymphatic fluid into the venous system, connecting to the left subclavian vein.

questions.text: In a RTA (road traffic accident), a person suffered from injury to the membranous urethra. What can be the location of the collection of the urine due to this injury? (Twisted PYQ)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Deep perineal pouch

 

Explanation:

 

Injury to the membranous urethra, which traverses through the urogenital diaphragm, leads to urine collection in specific anatomical spaces:

  1. The membranous urethra is surrounded by the external urethral sphincter within the deep perineal pouch
  2. When ruptured, urine initially collects in the deep perineal pouch due to the confined anatomical space
  3. The fascial boundaries of the deep perineal pouch limit the spread initially

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Peritoneal cavity: Incorrect. The membranous urethral injury doesn't communicate with the peritoneal cavity due to anatomical barriers.

 

Option C. Anterior abdominal wall: Incorrect. This is typically seen in bulbar urethral injuries where urine tracks along Buck's fascia into the anterior abdominal wall.

 

Option D. Ischiorectal fossa: Incorrect. While adjacent to the deep perineal pouch, the ischiorectal fossa is separated by fascial planes and isn't a primary collection site for membranous urethral injuries.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Membranous urethral injuries result in urine collection within the deep perineal pouch due to its anatomical location and fascial boundaries, unlike bulbar urethral injuries which track to the anterior abdominal wall.

questions.text:
The fibres of the internal oblique muscle and transversus abdominus muscle contribute to which boundaries of the inguinal canal walls? (INICET Nov 2023)

 

  1. Anterior wall
  2. Roof
  3. Floor
  4. Posterior wall
questions.solution:
Ans. A) ii and iv

 

 

 

The inguinal canal is an important structure in the anterior abdominal wall, with specific boundaries formed by different layers of muscles and fascia. The internal oblique is present in the lateral 1/3rd of anterior wall but transverse abdominis does not contribute to the anterior wall at all.

 

ii. Roof: The fibres of the internal oblique and transversus abdominis muscles, along with their conjoint tendon, form the roof of the inguinal canal.

 

iv. Posterior wall: The conjoint tendon, formed by the joining of the internal oblique and transversus abdominis muscles, also contributes to the posterior wall of the inguinal canal.

 

Other Options:

 

i. Anterior wall: The anterior wall of the inguinal canal is primarily formed by the external oblique aponeurosis, along with skin and superficial fascia. The internal oblique and transversus abdominis muscles do not contribute to the anterior wall.

 

iii. Floor: The floor of the inguinal canal is formed by the inguinal ligament, not by the internal oblique or transversus abdominis muscles.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The internal oblique and transversus abdominis muscles contribute to the roof and posterior wall of the inguinal canal through their conjoint tendon.

questions.text: Which of the following structures passing via jugular foramen has a separate canal?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Glossopharyngeal nerve

 

Explanation:

 

The glossopharyngeal nerve passing through the jugular foramen has a separate canal.

 

The glossopharyngeal nerve is the ninth cranial nerve, and it is responsible for providing sensory and motor innervation to the tongue, pharynx, and certain structures in the head and neck region. It originates in the brainstem, specifically from the medulla oblongata, and has both sensory and motor components.

 

The sensory branches of the glossopharyngeal nerve are responsible for providing sensation to the back of the tongue, tonsils, pharynx, middle ear, and the carotid sinus (which is a baroreceptor that helps regulate blood pressure). It also plays a role in taste sensation for the posterior third of the tongue.

 

The motor branches of the glossopharyngeal nerve are responsible for controlling the muscles of the pharynx and the parotid gland, which is a salivary gland located in the cheek. Dysfunction of the glossopharyngeal nerve can result in symptoms such as difficulty swallowing, decreased taste sensation, and a decreased gag reflex.

 

The glossopharyngeal nerve leaves the skull through the anteromedial part of the jugular foramen in a separate dural sheath.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hypoglossal Nerve (CN XII): The hypoglossal nerve passes through the hypoglossal canal, which is a separate opening located just anterior to the jugular foramen. This nerve controls the muscles of the tongue.

 

Option C. Vagus Nerve (CN X): The vagus nerve is another cranial nerve that passes through the jugular foramen. It does not have a separate canal within the jugular foramen. The vagus nerve has numerous functions, including control of the heart, lungs, and digestive organs.

 

Option D. Accessory Nerve (CN XI): The accessory nerve enters the jugular foramen alongside the vagus and glossopharyngeal nerves. It also does not have a separate canal within the jugular foramen. This nerve controls the sternocleidomastoid and trapezius muscles.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The glossopharyngeal nerve is unique among the nerves passing through the jugular foramen as it occupies a separate canal. Understanding this anatomical detail is vital for surgical navigation and for diagnosing nerve pathologies that may affect swallowing, taste, and autonomic functions in the neck and head region.

choices.text: Investing layer of deep cervical fascia

questions.text: A patient presents with swelling below the left earlobe and is experiencing pain. What is the most likely cause of this pain? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Greater auricular nerve

 

The greater auricular nerve is a sensory nerve that supplies the skin of the external ear, the area over the parotid gland, and the angle of the mandible. It is a branch of the cervical plexus, specifically arising from the cervical spinal nerves C2 and C3. Any acute inflammation of the gland such as acute sialadenitis results in pain in the preauricular region. The pain is mainly due to stretching of the capsule resulting in stimulation of the greater auricular nerve.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Facial nerve: The facial nerve (cranial nerve VII) traverses through the parotid gland but does not innervate it. Instead, it provides motor innervation to the muscles of facial expression. Damage to the facial nerve may lead to facial paralysis or weakness, but it's not directly responsible for sensation or pain below the earlobe.

 

Option B. Investing layer of deep cervical fascia: This is a layer of connective tissue that envelops the neck and extends into the face. It surrounds several structures, including the parotid gland. While the fascia itself isn't directly responsible for sensation, inflammation or infections that cause stretching of this fascia might contribute to discomfort.

 

Option C. Auriculotemporal nerve: This is a branch of the mandibular division of the trigeminal nerve (V3). It provides sensory innervation to the skin above the parotid gland, the external ear, and the external auditory canal. Though it provides sensation to the aforementioned areas, the region described in the scenario (below the earlobe) is not primarily innervated by the auriculotemporal nerve.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Greater auricular nerve originates from the cervical plexus, specifically from the C2 and C3 spinal nerves. It ascends to the parotid gland and provides sensory innervation to the skin over the parotid gland, the earlobe, and the area behind the ear, so the greater auricular nerve is most directly responsible for transmitting pain sensations from these regions.

questions.text: What is the nerve supply of the structure marked in the image below? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Median nerve

 

The marked structure is second lumbrical which is supplied by the median nerve.

 

The lateral two lumbricals are supplied by the median nerve and the medial two are supplied by the ulnar nerve. Function of these muscles is flexion at the metacarpophalangeal joints and extension at both the interphalangeal joints.

 

Median Nerve supplies the following intrinsic muscle of hand-

 

  • Thenar Muscles: Abductor pollicis brevis, flexor pollicis brevis, and opponens pollicis. (Note: The adductor pollicis is innervated by the ulnar nerve.)
  • Lumbricals: The median nerve innervates the first and second lumbricals, which flex the metacarpophalangeal joints of the index and middle fingers.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Posterior Interosseous Nerve (PIN): 

  • This nerve doesn't directly supply any of the intrinsic muscles of the hand. It's mainly responsible for innervating the extensor muscles of the forearm.

 

Option C. Anterior Interosseous Nerve (AIN): 

  • The AIN is a branch of the median nerve but doesn't directly supply the intrinsic muscles of the hand. Instead, it supplies deep muscles in the forearm, including flexor pollicis longus and the radial half of flexor digitorum profundus.

 

Option D. Ulnar Nerve: This nerve supply the following intrinsic muscle of hand

 

  • Hypothenar Muscles: Abductor digiti minimi, flexor digiti minimi brevis, and opponens digiti minimi.
  • Interossei: Both the dorsal and palmar interossei are innervated by the ulnar nerve. They are responsible for abduction and adduction of the fingers, respectively.
  • Third and Fourth Lumbricals: These lumbricals flex the metacarpophalangeal joints of the ring and little fingers.
  • Adductor Pollicis: This muscle, as mentioned before, is involved in thumb adduction and is innervated by the ulnar nerve.
  • Other Hand Muscles: Deep head of the flexor pollicis brevis and all the palmaris brevis muscles are also supplied by the ulnar nerve.

 

 

 

MCP = Metacarpophalangeal; IP = Interphalangeal; FDP = Flexor Digitorum Profundus.

questions.text: A woman with right-sided loss of sensations of both the upper and lower limb complains of shooting pain from her fingers to the right shoulder and a burning sensation when touching cold water. Motor functions are normal. Which of the following structures is likely to be involved? (INICET May 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Thalamus

 

The given clinical stem of a hemi-sensory loss and severe excruciating pain of the affected areas is suggestive of thalamic pain syndrome also known as Dejerine Roussy syndrome. Hence, thalamus marked as B is most likely to be involved.

 

The thalamus is a paired structure, with one thalamus on each side of the brain. It relays sensory and motor signals to the cerebral cortex and regulates consciousness, sleep, and alertness. The thalamus has multiple nuclei, each serving different functions. The ventral posterior nucleus, for instance, is vital for relaying somatosensory information. If the thalamus is damaged, it can lead to loss of sensation, and in certain cases, even cause the burning, shooting pain and abnormal temperature sensations described in the scenario, which aligns with the symptoms of thalamic syndrome.

 

 

The structures marked in the image are:

 

Option A.  A- Internal capsule

 

Option B. B- Thalamus

 

Option C. C- Subthalamic nucleus

 

Option D. D- Substantia nigra

 

Lesion in other three structures will lead to motor deficit and in question it is clearly mentioned that there is no motor deficit, only sensory deficit is the which  clearly indicates that the lesion lies in thalamus.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Internal capsule: The internal capsule is a bundle of white matter fibers that separates the caudate nucleus and the thalamus from the lenticular nucleus (putamen and globus pallidus). The anterior limb separates the head of the caudate from the lenticular nucleus, while the posterior limb separates the thalamus from the lenticular nucleus. It contains ascending and descending axonal fibers running between the cerebral cortex and the brainstem/spinal cord. Damage to the internal capsule, especially its posterior limb, can cause contralateral hemiparesis or hemiplegia (motor deficits). However, the woman's motor functions are described as normal, making this a less likely option given the scenario.

 

Option C. Subthalamic nucleus: The subthalamic nucleus is part of the basal ganglia circuit and is specifically associated with motor function. Lesions of the subthalamic nucleus, particularly on one side, might result in hemiballismus, which is characterized by violent, flinging movements of the contralateral limbs. It is not typically associated with sensory disturbances, or the pain described in the scenario.

 

Option D. Substantia nigra: The substantia nigra is in the midbrain and plays a critical role in reward, addiction, and movement. It contains dopamine-producing neurons. The degeneration of these neurons is a hallmark of Parkinson's disease. Lesions in the substantia nigra would primarily produce motor symptoms, such as rigidity, bradykinesia, and tremors. It would not typically lead to the sensory disturbances described in the scenario.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The thalamic pain syndrome is caused by the occlusion of these thalamic and thalamogeniculate branches. C/L hemisensory loss, which begins as numbness and escalates to cause intense burning pain in the affected areas, is what distinguishes it.

 

A thalamic lesion results in a breakdown in communication between the brain's afferent route and cortex because the thalamus serves as the site for the relay of sensory information between the periphery and cortex. The healing process following a thalamic infarct is painful.

questions.text: Artery supplying near marked structure is (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Anterior interventricular artery

 

The anterior interventricular artery, also known as the left anterior descending artery (LAD), supplies the anterior portion of the interventricular septum. This artery runs along the anterior interventricular groove and is critical in providing blood to the front part of the heart, including the septum and the left ventricle. The LAD is often referred to as the "widowmaker" artery because blockage of this artery can lead to severe myocardial infarction, which is often fatal.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Left circumflex artery: This artery supplies the lateral and posterior walls of the left ventricle but does not supply the anterior interventricular septum.

 

Option B. Left marginal artery: This artery branches off the circumflex artery and supplies the left ventricle's lateral wall, but it does not supply the interventricular septum.

 

Option D. Posterior interventricular artery: This artery supplies the posterior third of the interventricular septum but not the anterior portion. It runs in the posterior interventricular groove.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The anterior interventricular artery (LAD) supplies the anterior two-thirds of the interventricular septum and is critical for heart function, making it a key vessel in coronary circulation.

questions.text: Discharge of urine from umbilicus occurs in: (Twisted PYQ)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Urachal fistula

 

Explanation:

 

Urachal fistula is a congenital anomaly resulting from the incomplete obliteration of the urachus (a remnant of the allantois). Key features include:

  1. Forms a patent connection between the bladder and umbilicus
  2. Results in urinary discharge from the umbilicus
  3. Usually presents in early childhood
  4. May be associated with recurrent urinary tract infections
  5. Can be diagnosed with fistulograms or CT/MRI studies

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Gastroschisis: Incorrect. Presents with exposed bowel through an abdominal wall defect lateral to umbilicus without a covering membrane.

 

Option C. Omphalocele: Incorrect. Shows herniation of abdominal contents through umbilical ring with membrane coverage; no fistulous connection.

 

Option D. Ileal diverticulum: Incorrect. Meckel's diverticulum can cause fecal discharge if patent, but not urinary discharge.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Urachal fistula represents persistence of embryonic urachus, creating a pathway between bladder and umbilicus that results in urinary discharge, unlike other umbilical anomalies which don't typically cause urinary leakage.

questions.text: A patient who has taken the first COVID vaccine comes for the second dose. An astute nurse noticed that the shoulder was flabby, flat, and was asymmetrical. There was an associated loss of contour of the shoulder joint. Injury to which of the structures might have resulted and was avoidable?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Axillary nerve

 

The given clinical vignette is suggestive of injury to axillary nerve which leads to deltoid muscle palsy.

 

The deltoid muscle is supplied by the axillary nerve. Iatrogenic damage to the axillary nerve can happen during transaxillary procedures on the shoulder with lateral deltoid-splitting incisions or while administering IM injections inappropriately. But, note that this nerve is commonly injured during shoulder dislocation (most commonly anterior type) or fractures of the humeral neck as both the nerve and the posterior circumflex vessels (pass horizontally and posterior to the neck of the humerus).

 

 

Injury to the axillary nerve can lead to:

 

  • Weakness of abduction and lateral rotation of the arm
  • Retropulsion (extension of the shoulder with the arm abducted to 90 degrees) is impossible.
  • Atrophy of the Deltoid muscle leading to the loss of muscle contours of the shoulder
  • Loss of sensation in the Regimental badge area

 

The described symptoms point towards a condition known as "Shoulder Injury Related to Vaccine Administration" (SIRVA). SIRVA can occur if the vaccine is injected too high in the upper arm, potentially causing inflammation or damage to the structures underlying the deltoid muscle, especially the axillary nerve.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Rotator Cuff: The rotator cuff is a group of four muscles (supraspinatus, infraspinatus, teres minor, and subscapularis) that stabilize and allow various movements of the shoulder joint. Injury to the rotator cuff often results from trauma, repetitive use, or degeneration and leads to pain, especially with overhead activities, and weakness in the arm. A rotator cuff injury would not typically cause the "flabby, flat, asymmetrical" appearance described unless there was a significant tear and muscle atrophy. However, this type of injury wouldn't be directly associated with vaccine administration.

 

Option B. Posterior Circumflex Artery: The posterior circumflex humeral artery is a branch of the axillary artery that runs posteriorly around the surgical neck of the humerus. Injury to this artery might result in bleeding and potentially hematoma formation but wouldn't lead to the described flabby, flat appearance of the shoulder or loss of contour.

 

Option C. Lateral Cutaneous Nerve of Arm: The lateral cutaneous nerve of the arm, also known as the lateral brachial cutaneous nerve, is a sensory nerve that provides sensation to the lateral part of the upper arm. Injury to this nerve would result in sensory loss or tingling in its distribution area but would not cause the observed morphological changes or affect the contour of the shoulder.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The axillary nerve arises from the posterior cord of the brachial plexus and supplies the deltoid muscle and the teres minor muscle. It also carries sensory fibers for the skin over a part of the deltoid (known as the "regimental badge area").

 

Damage to the axillary nerve can result from shoulder dislocations or, as in this case, a vaccine administered too high on the arm. Injury to the axillary nerve would cause paralysis of the deltoid muscle, leading to a flat shoulder appearance and loss of the normal rounded contour of the deltoid. Over time, if the nerve does not recover, the deltoid muscle may atrophy, further accentuating the flat appearance.

questions.text: In a patient with Horner syndrome, ptosis is most likely due to paralysis of which of the following muscles? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Superior tarsal muscle

 

The superior tarsal muscle, also known as Muller's muscle, is a smooth muscle that assists in elevating the upper eyelid. In Horner syndrome, there is damage to the sympathetic nerve supply, specifically the T1 nerve, which innervates the superior tarsal muscle. Paralysis of this muscle leads to ptosis, or drooping of the upper eyelid, because the muscle cannot perform its function of aiding eyelid elevation. Horner syndrome typically results from a disruption in the sympathetic nerves, leading to symptoms like ptosis, miosis (constricted pupil), and anhidrosis (lack of sweating).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Orbitalis: This muscle provides support to the eyeball from the back. In Horner syndrome, although the orbitalis muscle may be affected, leading to a sunken appearance of the eyeball (apparent enophthalmos), it does not contribute directly to ptosis.

 

Option B. Levator superioris palpebrae: This muscle is primarily responsible for the elevation of the eyelid. However, it is innervated by the oculomotor nerve (cranial nerve III), not by the sympathetic nervous system, and its paralysis leads to significant ptosis, but this condition is unrelated to Horner syndrome.

 

Option C. Orbicularis Oculi: This muscle is responsible for closing the eyelid and is innervated by the facial nerve (cranial nerve VII). Paralysis of this muscle leads to inability to close the eyelid but is not involved in ptosis due to Horner syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Horner syndrome is characterized by ptosis due to paralysis of the superior tarsal muscle (Muller's muscle), which is innervated by sympathetic fibers, particularly from the T1 spinal nerve

questions.text: Marked structure is connected to which part of basal nuclei (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Corpus striatum

 

The marked structure in the provided image is the substantia nigra, identified by its pigmented appearance. The substantia nigra is a crucial component of the basal nuclei, involved in the regulation of movement.

 

The substantia nigra communicates with the basal nuclei through the nigrostriatal pathway, which is composed of dopaminergic neurons connecting the substantia nigra to the corpus striatum. This pathway plays a significant role in the modulation of motor activities and is notably affected in Parkinson's disease.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Thalamus: Incorrect because the thalamus primarily acts as a relay station for sensory and motor signals to the cerebral cortex and does not directly connect with the substantia nigra in the context of the basal nuclei.

 

Option B. Subthalamic nucleus: Incorrect because while it is a component of the basal nuclei, it is not the primary structure connected to the substantia nigra in the context of the nigrostriatal pathway.

 

Option C. Globus pallidum: Incorrect because the globus pallidum is involved in regulating voluntary movement but does not have the direct nigrostriatal connection as the corpus striatum does with the substantia nigra.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The substantia nigra is connected to the corpus striatum through the nigrostriatal pathway, which is essential for motor control.

questions.text: Type I collagen is not seen in? (AIIMS Nov 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Elastic cartilage

 

Elastic cartilage, as the name suggests, is more elastic than other types of cartilage. This is due to the presence of elastic fibers interspersed with the cartilage cells (chondrocytes).

 

The primary collagen in elastic cartilage is Type II collagen, not Type I.

 

Additionally, the elastin present in this cartilage gives it a yellowish appearance and makes it flexible. Examples of elastic cartilage include the external ear (auricle) and the epiglottis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Bone: Bone tissue primarily consists of Type I collagen. This collagen provides a framework upon which hydroxyapatite (a crystalline structure made of calcium and phosphate) can deposit, giving bones their characteristic rigidity and strength. Type I collagen provides the bone with some flexibility and tensile strength, which helps to prevent fractures.

 

Option B. Ligament: Ligaments, which connect bone to bone, are primarily composed of Type I collagen. This gives ligaments their tensile strength and ability to withstand pulling forces. The presence of Type I collagen in ligaments helps in maintaining joint stability.

 

Option C. Aponeurosis: An aponeurosis is a flat, sheet-like tendinous structure that attaches muscle to bone or other tissues. Like tendons, aponeuroses primarily contain Type I collagen. This allows aponeuroses to transmit muscular forces effectively.

 

Educational Objective:

 

List of types of collagens in various tissues:

choices.text: Basal lamina lining the serous acini
Presence of serous acini with acidophilic tip

questions.text: Which of the following features differentiates the exocrine pancreas from the parotid gland? (INICET May 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Absence of striated duct

 

Absence of striated duct in exocrine pancreas differentiates it from the parotid gland.

 

The exocrine pancreas is comprised entirely of serous acini. Therefore, its general structure is similar to that of the parotid gland, but the two are easily distinguished by:

 

  1. The parotid gland has striated and intercalated intralobular ducts, whereas the pancreas has only the intercalated type.
  2. The excretory ducts of the parotid gland are striated columnar, whereas the excretory duct of the pancreas is a simple columnar.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Basal lamina lining the serous acini: Both exocrine pancreas and parotid gland have serous acini that are lined by a basal lamina. Basal lamina is a thin extracellular matrix layer that underlies epithelial tissues and surrounds the cells in muscles, fat, and Schwann cells. So, this feature does not differentiate the two.

 

Option C. Presence of serous acini with acidophilic tip: Both the exocrine pancreas and the parotid gland have serous acini. In the pancreas, these acinar cells have an acidophilic (eosinophilic) cytoplasm because they contain zymogen granules, which are precursors of digestive enzymes. The parotid gland is purely serous, and its acinar cells also have zymogen granules. Thus, this feature does not uniquely differentiate the two glands.

 

Option D. Presence of apical acinar villi: While the exocrine pancreas has acinar cells with a fine, microvillous border at the apical side (facing the lumen) to increase the secretory surface, this is not a feature that starkly contrasts with the parotid gland. Acinar cells in the parotid gland also have secretory granules toward their apical side.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Striated ducts are a characteristic feature of salivary glands, including the parotid gland. These ducts have basal infoldings associated with mitochondria, which gives them their "striated" appearance. They play a role in modifying the primary saliva produced by the acinar cells. The exocrine pancreas does not possess striated ducts. Instead, it has intercalated ducts that connect the acinar cells to the larger duct system. This feature, therefore, differentiates the exocrine pancreas from the parotid gland.

questions.text:
When asked the patient to stand on left foot, right side went down. Which structures are involved in this case? (INICET NOV 2023)

 

 

 

  1. Superior gluteal nerve
  2. Gluteus minimus
  3. Gluteus medius
  4. Sciatic nerve
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1, 2, 3

 

 

 

This question describes a clinical scenario where a patient is exhibiting a positive Trendelenburg sign. When asked to stand on the left foot, the patient's right side drops, indicating a problem with the muscles or nerves responsible for maintaining hip stability. The Trendelenburg sign indicates weakness or paralysis of the muscles innervated by the superior gluteal nerve.

 

1. Superior Gluteal Nerve: This nerve innervates the gluteus medius, gluteus minimus, and tensor fasciae latae muscles. Damage to this nerve can lead to weakness in these muscles.

 

2. Gluteus Minimus: This muscle, along with the gluteus medius, helps to stabilize the pelvis during walking. Weakness or paralysis of the gluteus minimus results in the inability to maintain a level pelvis.

 

3. Gluteus Medius: This muscle is crucial for hip abduction and pelvic stabilization. Weakness or paralysis causes the pelvis to drop on the side opposite to the stance leg.

 

Other Option:

 

4. Sciatic nerve: The sciatic nerve does not innervate the gluteus medius or minimus. Its primary functions involve the muscles of the posterior thigh and lower leg. Damage to the sciatic nerve would not cause a Trendelenburg sign.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A positive Trendelenburg sign, where the pelvis drops on the opposite side when standing on one foot, indicates weakness or paralysis of the gluteus medius and minimus muscles, which are innervated by the superior gluteal nerve.

choices.text: It occurs due to the persistence of prochordal plate
It occurs due to the defective migration of primordial cells to the genital ridge
It contains skin, cartilage and bone
It is a benign tumor of coccyx

questions.text: Which of the following statements is wrong about the clinical pediatric case as shown in the image? (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) It occurs due to the persistence of prochordal plate

 

 

 

The image shows a sacrococcygeal teratoma, which is a tumor located at the base of the coccyx in newborns. It is the most common tumor in neonates, and its origin and characteristics are well understood.

 

  • Persistence of Primitive Streak: Sacrococcygeal teratomas arise from the remnants of the primitive streak, not from the prochordal plate. The primitive streak is a structure in early embryonic development that usually regresses, but if remnants persist, they can lead to the formation of these tumors.
  • Defective Migration of Primordial Cells: This statement is correct as primordial germ cells that fail to migrate properly to the genital ridge can contribute to the formation of teratomas.
  • Contains Skin, Cartilage, and Bone: Teratomas are composed of tissues derived from all three germ layers: ectoderm, mesoderm, and endoderm. Therefore, they can contain a variety of tissue types including skin, cartilage, and bone.
  • Benign Tumor of Coccyx: Sacrococcygeal teratomas are generally benign, although they can sometimes be malignant.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Defective migration of primordial cells to the genital ridge: This statement is correct. Defective migration can result in teratomas.

 

Option C. Contains skin, cartilage, and bone: This statement is correct as teratomas can contain these tissues.

 

Option D. Benign tumor of coccyx: This statement is correct as sacrococcygeal teratomas are often benign.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Sacrococcygeal teratomas arise from the remnants of the primitive streak and can contain various tissues including skin, cartilage, and bone. They are typically benign tumors located at the base of the coccyx.

questions.text: A patient sustained an injury to the head and now presents with blood collected around his eyes. Attachment of which of the following structures leads to this condition? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Loose areolar layer

 

Explanation:

 

The condition, where blood collects around the eyes following a head injury, is known as "raccoon eyes" or "black eyes".

 

Layers of the scalp -

 

The scalp consists of five layers, which can be remembered using the mnemonic "SCALP":

 

  1. Skin
  2. Connective tissue (superficial fascia)
  3. Aponeurotic layer (epicranial aponeurosis)
  4. Loose areolar layer
  5. Periosteum (pericranium)

 

 

Among these layers, the loose areolar layer (4th layer) is the key to understanding the development of raccoon eyes. This layer lacks bony attachments anteriorly and is continuous with the eyelids. When a head injury occurs, the emissary veins or other vessels in this layer may rupture, causing blood to accumulate. Since the loose areolar layer is continuous with the eyelids, the blood can easily spread and collect around the eyes, resulting in the characteristic black eye appearance.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Superficial fascia: Incorrect. Although the superficial fascia is one of the layers of the scalp, it is not the layer responsible for the continuity with the eyelids and the development of raccoon eyes.

 

Option C. Periosteum: Incorrect. The periosteum, also known as the pericranium, is the innermost layer of the scalp, firmly attached to the underlying bone. It does not have continuity with the eyelids and is not the cause of raccoon eyes.

 

Option D. Pericranium: Incorrect. The pericranium is another name for the periosteum, the innermost layer of the scalp. It is not responsible for the development of raccoon eyes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The loose areolar layer of the scalp, which lacks bony attachments anteriorly and is continuous with the eyelids, is responsible for the development of raccoon eyes following a head injury due to the accumulation and spread of blood from ruptured vessels.

questions.text: From which germ layer are astrocytes derived? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Neuroectoderm

 

Explanation:

 

Astrocytes are derived from neuroectoderm. Neuroectoderm is a specialized portion of ectoderm that forms the neural tube and neural crest. The neural tube gives rise to the central nervous system, including neurons and neuroglial cells. Astrocytes are a type of neuroglial cell that form within the central nervous system. They develop from glioblasts (also called spongioblasts), which in turn derive from the germinal neuroepithelial cells of the neural tube wall after they cease to produce neuroblasts.

 

Other Options:

 

Option a) Mesoderm - This is incorrect because mesoderm gives rise to structures like bone, cartilage, muscle, blood, connective tissue, and the urogenital system. While mesoderm contributes to the vascular elements in the nervous system and forms microglia (which are mesodermal in origin), it does not form astrocytes.

 

Option c) Endoderm - This is incorrect because endoderm gives rise to the epithelial lining of the respiratory tract, gastrointestinal tract, bladder, and associated glands. Endoderm has no role in forming any components of the central nervous system, including astrocytes.

 

Option d) None - This is incorrect because astrocytes definitely have a germ layer of origin, which is neuroectoderm.

 

Education Objective: 

 

Astrocytes are neuroglial cells that develop from glioblasts derived from the neuroepithelial cells of the neural tube, making them neuroectodermal in origin. This is consistent with most of the cellular elements of the central nervous system which derive from neuroectoderm

questions.text: Based on the histological image, which hormone would be produced by the follicular cells in thyroid gland? (Twisted PYQ)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Thyroxine

 

Explanation:

 

The image shows thyroid tissue with follicular cells:

  1. Form the main epithelial component of thyroid follicles
  2. Are responsible for producing thyroid hormones (T3 and T4/Thyroxine)
  3. Store hormones in colloid within follicular lumens
  4. Actively take up iodine for hormone synthesis
  5. Are regulated by TSH from anterior pituitary

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Adrenaline: Incorrect. This is produced by adrenal medulla, not thyroid follicular cells.

 

Option B. Calcitonin: Incorrect. This is produced by parafollicular cells (C cells) marked by the arrow in the image, not by follicular cells.

 

Option C. Prolactin: Incorrect. This is produced by lactotrophs of anterior pituitary, not thyroid tissue.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Thyroid follicular cells, which form the wall of thyroid follicles, are responsible for synthesis and secretion of thyroid hormones (T3 and T4), while parafollicular cells produce calcitonin.

choices.text: It is the meeting point of frontal, parietal, temporal and sphenoid bones.
Blow to the lateral side of the skull injures the marked structure.
Accessory middle meningeal artery lies under this structure.
It corresponds to site of anterolateral fontanelle of fetal skull.

questions.text: Identify the incorrect statement regarding the marked structure: (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Accessory middle meningeal artery lies under this structure.

 

Explanation:

 

The structure marked in the image is the pterion. The main branch of Middle meningeal artery lies under this structure NOT accessory middle meningeal artery. The accessory middle meningeal artery usually arises from the maxillary artery and enters the middle cranial fossa through the foramen ovale or a separate foramen. Its location and presence can vary.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. It is the meeting point of frontal, parietal, temporal, and sphenoid bones. Correct: The pterion is indeed the meeting point of these four bones.

 

Option B. Blow to the lateral side of the skull injures the marked structure. Correct: A blow to the pterion can be very dangerous because the middle meningeal artery runs just deep to this area, on the inner side of the skull. If this artery is ruptured due to a fracture at the pterion, it can lead to an epidural hematoma, which is a type of traumatic brain injury.
